text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t think there’s a conspiracy. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: If that’s where you’re going. Family Member: Right. Yeah. Doctor: This is not a trial. It’s an FDA-approved study. Where there is a trial- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - is we want to know whether your immune system is reacting to it. So our study isn’t whether you get the medicine or not. You get the medicine, regardless. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Our study is, will you allow me to get extra tubes of blood so I can measure these things that are affecting the immune system, so we get knowledge? That’s it. So there is no sugar. Family Member: Right. Doctor: There is no, you know, what we call placebo, or there is nothing that is not what is the treatment coming to you. Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That also tells you about chemo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The vitamin C part would only be done here. Patient: Right. Is that you have therapy, you’re not ready to go to chemotherapy, I’m willing to try something under our observations with blood tests and scans. That if the cancer would sort of wildly changing, we abort and do chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. So, that would be sort of, in some ways, a gamble. Doctor: And, then, the third one is we draw blood tests today, just to see the AR-V7 positive. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
